entry.title: SAP 分析云经验分享：如何批量修改日历流程被分派者
entry.content:
SAP 分析云经验分享：如何批量修改日历流程被分派者 

一、介绍 

在当今数字化驱动、企业追求卓越运营的时代，SAP 分析云作为一款功能强大的综合性工具，正全方位助力企业提升决策效能与管理秩序。它承载着数据可视化、预测分析、规划以及协作等多重使命，为企业勾勒出一幅智能管理的宏伟蓝图。 

然而，随着企业版图的拓展、业务流程的精细化以及团队协作的深度化，我们对 SAP 分析云各项功能的期许也在不断攀升。聚焦于 SAP 分析云中的日历功能，尽管它在事件安排、流程追踪等方面表现出色，但目前的筛选机制存在一定的局限性，筛选涉及事件相关人员时，仅能依据 “我的角色” 进行筛选，难以满足企业多元且复杂的管理诉求。 

试想这样的情境：当员工 A 因休假暂别岗位，事件 1 的流程负责人 B 想要迅速梳理出该事件下，由 A 负责且尚未完成的子任务，并重新调配人力，却因为筛选功能的限制，操作时会遇到一些困难；当员工 A 离职，日历管理员肩负起在海量日历数据中，逐一查找 A 身影并进行批量替换的重任，面对冗长且繁琐的操作流程，效率有所降低。为了解决这一痛点，我开发了一个使用了日历API脚本的故事应用。这篇文章中，我将为大家详细介绍。 

二、如何使用“批量修改日历流程被分派者”应用 

使用该故事应用前可在该故事页面查看相关故事应用的使用说明。 

1、要执行此操作，您需要具备以下权限： 

  • 分析模型的“读”权限 
  • 公共文件的“管理”权限 
  • 私有文件的“读”权限 

2、请按照以下步骤获取父日历流程的事件 ID： 

  • 点击导航栏中的“日历”，并选择您要编辑的事件。 

  • 当事件页面打开时，复制 浏览器地址栏中URL中“eventId=” 后面的部分以获取事件 ID。 

或者： 

  • 选中事件后，点击右上角的“详细信息”，在弹出菜单栏的右上角，点击“更多”，然后点击“事件设置”。 

  • 如果未勾选“允许外部 API 访问”选项，请勾选该选项。 

 

  • 然后点击“显示详情”以查看并复制事件 ID。 

3、将事件 ID 粘贴到文本框中。 

4、使用下拉菜单选择您要替换的被分派者。 

5、使用下拉菜单选择您要添加的新被分派者。 

6、点击 “Confirm and Replace” 按钮。 

  • 对于替换成功的事件，系统会弹出绿色窗口以提示替换完成。 
  • 任务全部完成后，系统会弹出灰色窗口，提示“Finished processing all processes and tasks”表示任务已全部完成。 

  • 如果在替换整个流程的过程中存在未被替换成功的事件，则会提示未替换成功的事件数量以及对应的事件ID和事件名称。 

三、注意事项 

1、仅可在父流程中使用，不支持其他类型的日历事件。如果在输入框中输入非流程事件的事件ID，如常规任务的事件ID，则会提示“Only events with the event type of "Process" can be modified. Please enter the Event ID of an event with the event type of "Process".” 

2、无法替换状态为“已取消、失败、成功或部分成功”的任务的指派对象。 

3、无法替换数据锁定任务、数据操作任务、多操作任务、输入任务或发布任务的指派对象。 

四、代码实现 

接下来将对主要的实现逻辑进行介绍 。Calendar提供了比较丰富的集成API ，通过利用相关 API 可实现以上功能。主要逻辑步骤如下： 

1、变量初始化与界面设置 

在实现该功能之前，需要在故事应用中配置“日历集成”，并完成变量的初始化。以下是部分关键变量的说明： 

RemovedAssignee // 想要替换的被分派者 
AddedAssignee // 想要添加的被分派者 
calendarEventId // 相关日历的事件 ID 
removeAssigneeFilterSelection // 下拉菜单实现移除assignee的脚本变量 
addAssigneeFilterSelection // 下拉菜单实现添加assignee的脚本变量   
count // 用来记录没有替换成功的事件的数量 
arrayFailedEvent  // 替换失败的事件集合（事件Id） 
arrayFailedEventName //替换失败的时间集合（事件名称）

同时，可以对加载状态的呈现方式和系统消息提示类型进行相应的预设与配置。 

2、获取事件对象并进行校验 

首先，根据 calendarEventId 获取对应的事件对象 task，并对其存在性进行校验。随后判断该事件的类型是否为“流程类型”（Process）：若类型不符，则提示用户仅支持对“流程类型”的事件进行操作，并中止后续执行。 

var task = calIntegration1.getCalendarEventById(calendarEventId); 
if(task === undefined){ 
Application.showMessage( 
ApplicationMessageType.Warning, 
"The event ID you entered is incorrect. Please verify and re-enter it." 
); 
//用来控制加载状态   
   Application.hideBusyIndicator(); 
return; 
} 
//添加一个判断 判断用户输入事件的事件类型是流程还是其他     
if(task.getType() !== CalendarTaskType.Process ){ 
Application.showMessage( 
ApplicationMessageType.Warning, 
"Only events with the event type of \"Process\" can be modified. Please enter the Event ID of an event with the event type of \"Process.\"" 
); 
//用来控制加载状态    
Application.hideBusyIndicator(); 
return; 
}

3、处理根流程任务 

将事件对象转换为 CalendarProcess 类型。 

对根流程执行被分派者移除（removeAssignee）操作。 

  • 如果移除成功，则执行添加新负责人（addAssignee）。 
  • 根据操作成功与否，输出对应的提示。 
  • 如果失败，记录失败信息并加入失败数组。 
var task_process = cast(Type.CalendarProcess,task); 
// 创建队列并初始化（使用数组模拟队列） 
var eventQueue = ArrayUtils.create(Type.CalendarProcess);  
// 将根流程加入队列 
eventQueue.push(task_process);  
var assigneeRemoved_root = task_process.removeAssignee(RemovedAssignee);  
//用来控制加载状态  
Application.hideBusyIndicator();  
//判断根流程是否删除assignee成功 
 if(assigneeRemoved_root) {  
    Application.showMessage(ApplicationMessageType.Success, "Assignee has been successfully removeded to Calendar Event " ); 
     //只有根流程assignee删除成功后才会给根流程添加assignee        
      var assigneeAdded_root = task_process.addAssignee(AddedAssignee);     
    //判断根流程是否添加assignee成功     
    if(assigneeAdded_root) {   
           Application.showMessage(ApplicationMessageType.Success, "Assignee has been successfully addded to Calendar Event " ); 
     }   
     else {   
           Application.showMessage(ApplicationMessageType.Error, "Assignee has failed to be added to Calendar Event "); 
     }  
}   
   else {   
       Application.showMessage(ApplicationMessageType.Error, "Assignee has failed to be removed to Calendar Event "); 
       count++; 
       arrayFailedEventName.push(calIntegration1.getCalendarEventById(calendarEventId).getName());  
       arrayFailedEvent.push(calendarEventId); 
   }

4、广度优先遍历所有的子流程和子任务 

对队列 eventQueue 进行广度优先遍历所有子事件。 

对每一个子事件执行： 

  • 获取其对象。 
  • 如果是流程类型，继续加入队列遍历其子项。 
  • 对每个子项尝试移除原被分派者，成功后尝试添加新被分派者。 
  • 成功与否都记录日志和信息，失败的加入失败数组。 
// 广度优先遍历处理所有流程    
while (eventQueue.length > 0) { 
    // 从队列头部取出当前流程     
    var currentProcess = eventQueue.shift(); 
    // 获取当前流程的所有子项（子流程或子任务）  
    var childrenIds = currentProcess.getChildren(); 
    // 遍历所有子项    
    for (var i = 0; i < childrenIds.length; i++) { 
        var childEvent = calIntegration1.getCalendarEventById(childrenIds[i]);  
        // 如果是子流程，加入队列继续处理其子项    
        if (childEvent.getType() === CalendarTaskType.Process) { 
            var childProcess = cast(Type.CalendarProcess, childEvent); 
            eventQueue.push(childProcess); // 将子流程加入队列   
        }     
        // 对当前子项（无论流程还是任务）执行移除操作   
        var assigneeRemoved = childEvent.removeAssignee(RemovedAssignee); 
        // 处理删除操作结果   
        if (assigneeRemoved) { 
            Application.showMessage( 
                ApplicationMessageType.Success, 
                "Assignee removed from: " + childEvent.getId() 
            ); 
           var assigneeAdded = childEvent.addAssignee(AddedAssignee); 
           // 处理添加操作结果     
     if (assigneeAdded) { 
         Application.showMessage( 
         ApplicationMessageType.Success, 
         "Assignee added to: " + childEvent.getId() 
          );  
     } 
     else { 
         Application.showMessage( 
         ApplicationMessageType.Error, 
         "Failed to add to: " + childEvent.getId() 
         ); 
     }  
  }  
       else { 
               count++; 
               arrayFailedEvent.push(childEvent.getId());                                    arrayFailedEventName.push(calIntegration1.getCalendarEventById(childEvent.getId()).getName());  
       Application.showMessage( 
                ApplicationMessageType.Error, 
                "Failed to remove from: " + childEvent.getId() 
                                 ); 
       }    
    } 
}

5、输出错误信息和结果提示 

  •  如果有失败的事件，显示失败数量。 
  • 对每一个失败事件，显示事件名和 ID。 
  • 最后输出“任务处理完成”提示信息。 
var count_string = ConvertUtils.numberToString(count); 
// 判断是否有未替换成功的事件，如果有，输出未替换成功的事件数量   
if(count !== 0){ 
Application.showMessage( 
               ApplicationMessageType.Warning, 
               "You have \"" + count_string + "\" events where the assignee failed to be replaced successfully."  
              ); 
}  
for (var j = 0; j < count; j++) { 
               warningMessage = warningMessage + "The assignee of event  \"" + arrayFailedEventName[j]  + "\" failed to be replaced successfully.\n"; 
               warningMessage = warningMessage + " the event ID: " + arrayFailedEvent[j] + "\n\n"; 
} 
if (warningMessage) { 
               Application.showMessage( 
               ApplicationMessageType.Warning, 
               warningMessage 
              ); 
} 
//任务执行结束   
Application.showMessage( 
              ApplicationMessageType.Info, 
             "Finished processing all processes and tasks" 
);

五、总结 

本文主要分享了我开发“批量修改日历流程被分派者”故事应用的经验。如果您也遇到了类似的问题，希望可以给您启发。

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud Experience Sharing: How to Batch Modify the Assignees of Calendar Processes
entry.content:
SAP Analytics Cloud Experience Sharing: How to Batch Modify the Assignees of Calendar Processes

I. Introduction

In today's digital - driven era where businesses strive for excellence in operations, SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)  serves as a powerful all - in - one tool. It boosts enterprises' decision - making efficiency and managerial order, handling data visualization, predictive analysis, planning, and collaboration. It draws a grand blueprint for intelligent business management.

Yet, as companies expand, refine their business processes, and deepen teamwork, the demands on SAC's features are also increasing. Focusing on its calendar function, although it performs well in event scheduling and process tracking, its filtering mechanism is somewhat limited. When filtering for event - related individuals, it only allows filtering by "My Roles", which can't satisfy the diverse and complex management needs of enterprises.

Consider this scenario: When employee A takes a leave, event 1's process owner B wants to quickly identify the incomplete sub - tasks under this event assigned to A and reallocate human resources. However, due to the limitations of the filtering function, the operation will encounter some difficulties. When employee A leaves the company, the calendar administrator has to take on the onerous task of searching for A in massive amounts of calendar data and replacing them one by one. Facing the lengthy and complicated operational process, the efficiency is reduced. To address this pain point, I have developed a story application using a calendar API script. In this article, I will introduce it to you in detail.

II. How to Use the "Calendar Process Assignee Batch Modification" Application

Before using this story app, you can find its usage instructions on the story page.

1. To perform this action, you need the following permissions:

  • Read access to the Analytical Model.
  • Manage access to Public Files.
  • Read access to Private Files.

2. Please follow these steps to get the event ID of the parent calendar process:

  • Click “Calendar” in the navigation bar and select the event you want to edit.

  • When the event page opens, copy the part after “eventId=” in the browser's address bar URL to get the event ID.

Alternatively:

  • After selecting the event, click "Details" in the top - right corner. Then, in the top - right corner of the pop - up menu, click "More", and then click "Event Settings".

  • If the “Allow External API Access” option isn't checked, please check it.

  • Then click “Show Details” to view and copy the event ID.

3. Paste the event ID into the text box.

4. Use the dropdown menu to select the assignee you want to replace.

5. Use the dropdown menu again to select the new assignee you want to add.

6. Click the "Confirm and Replace" button.

  • For events where replacement is successful, a green window will pop up to indicate completion.
  • Once all tasks are finished, a gray window will appear with the message "Finished processing all processes and tasks" to indicate that everything is complete.

 

  • If there are events that failed to replace during the entire process replacement, the system will prompt the number of events that were not successfully replaced, as well as the corresponding event IDs and names.

III. Notes

1. For Process Events Only

  • Can only be used on a parent process, other types of calendar events are not supported. If you input the event ID of a non - process event, such as a General task, the system will display a prompt: "Only events with the event type of'Process' can be modified. Please enter the Event ID of an event with the event type of 'Process'."

2. Restrictions on Task Status

  • Cannot replace assignees of tasks  with statuses of "Canceled, Failed, Successful, or Partially Successful".   

3. Restrictions on Task Type

  • Cannot replace assignees of Data Locking Tasks, Data Action Tasks, Multi Action Tasks, Input Tasks, or Publications.

IV. Code Implementation

Next, I'll introduce the main implementation logic. Calendar offers a wide range of integration APIs, and the above functions can be realised by using relevant APIs. The major logic steps are as follows:

1. Variable Initialisation and Interface Settings

Before implementing this function, you need to configure “Calendar Integration” in the story app and initialise the variables. Here are some key variables:

RemovedAssignee // The assignee to be replaced
AddedAssignee // The new assignee to be added
calendarEventId // The event ID of the relevant calendar
removeAssigneeFilterSelection // Script variable for the dropdown to remove an assignee
addAssigneeFilterSelection // Script variable for the dropdown to add an assignee
count // Counter for events that failed to replace
arrayFailedEvent // Collection of failed event IDs
arrayFailedEventName // Collection of failed event names

You can also preset and configure the display of loading states and the type of system message prompts.

2. Get the Event Object and Perform Validation

First, get the corresponding event object task based on  calendarEventId and check whether it exists.Then check whether the event type is "Process". If not, notify the user that this feature only supports "Process" - type events and stop further execution.

var task = calIntegration1.getCalendarEventById(calendarEventId); 
if(task === undefined){ 
               Application.showMessage( 
               ApplicationMessageType.Warning, 
               "The event ID you entered is incorrect. Please verify and re-enter it." 
); 
               // used to manage the loading state.
               Application.hideBusyIndicator(); 
               return; 
} 
// Add a check to determine whether the event type of the user - entered event is a process or something else.
if(task.getType() !== CalendarTaskType.Process ){ 
               Application.showMessage( 
               ApplicationMessageType.Warning, 
               "Only events with the event type of \"Process\" can be modified. Please enter the Event ID of an event with the event type of \"Process.\"" 
); 
               // used to manage the loading state.
               Application.hideBusyIndicator(); 
               return; 
}

3. Process the Root Process Task

Cast the event object to the CalendarProcess type.

Perform the removeAssignee operation on the root process.

  • If removal succeeds, add the new assignee using addAssignee.
  • Output corresponding messages based on operation success or failure.
  • If it fails, log the failure info and add it to the failure array.
var task_process = cast(Type.CalendarProcess,task);
// Create and initialize a queue (using an array to simulate a queue).
var eventQueue = ArrayUtils.create(Type.CalendarProcess); 
// Enqueue the root process.
eventQueue.push(task_process); 
var assigneeRemoved_root = task_process.removeAssignee(RemovedAssignee); 
// Used to control the loading status. 
Application.hideBusyIndicator(); 
// Check if removing the assignee from the process root was successful.
 if(assigneeRemoved_root) { 
     Application.showMessage(ApplicationMessageType.Success, "Assignee has been successfully removeded to Calendar Event " );    
      // Add the new assignee to the root process only after the assignee deletion is confirmed to be successful.
      var assigneeAdded_root = task_process.addAssignee(AddedAssignee);    
      // Check if adding the assignee to the root process was successful.
      if(assigneeAdded_root) {  
            Application.showMessage(ApplicationMessageType.Success, "Assignee has been successfully addded to Calendar Event " );
      }  
      else {  
            Application.showMessage(ApplicationMessageType.Error, "Assignee has failed to be added to Calendar Event ");
      } 
 }  
    else {  
        Application.showMessage(ApplicationMessageType.Error, "Assignee has failed to be removed to Calendar Event ");
        count++;
       arrayFailedEventName.push(calIntegration1.getCalendarEventById(calendarEventId).getName()); 
        arrayFailedEvent.push(calendarEventId);
    }

4. Traverse All Subprocesses and Subtasks Using BFS

Perform a breadth - first traversal of all sub - events in the eventQueue.

For each sub - event:

  • Get its object.
  • If it's a process type, enqueue it to traverse its sub - items.
  • For each sub - item, try to remove the original assignee. If successful, add the new assignee.
  • Record logs and info regardless of success or failure. Add failed ones to the failure array.
// Process all tasks via breadth - first traversal.    
while (eventQueue.length > 0) { 
    // Remove the current process from the front of the queue.    
    var currentProcess = eventQueue.shift(); 
    // Retrieve all sub - items (sub - processes or sub - tasks) of the current process.
    var childrenIds = currentProcess.getChildren(); 
// Traverse all sub - items.
    for (var i = 0; i < childrenIds.length; i++) { 
        var childEvent = calIntegration1.getCalendarEventById(childrenIds[i]);               
        // If a sub - item is a sub - process, add it to the queue for further processing of its own sub - items.    
        if (childEvent.getType() === CalendarTaskType.Process) { 
            var childProcess = cast(Type.CalendarProcess, childEvent); 
            eventQueue.push(childProcess); // Add the sub - process to the queue.  
        }          
        // Perform the removal operation on the current sub - item (whether it's a process or a task).   
        var assigneeRemoved = childEvent.removeAssignee(RemovedAssignee); 
        // Process the deletion - operation result.  
        if (assigneeRemoved) { 
            Application.showMessage( 
                ApplicationMessageType.Success, 
                "Assignee removed from: " + childEvent.getId() 
            ); 
           var assigneeAdded = childEvent.addAssignee(AddedAssignee); 
                 // Process the addition - operation result.     
                if (assigneeAdded) { 
                              Application.showMessage( 
                                  ApplicationMessageType.Success, 
                                  "Assignee added to: " + childEvent.getId() 
                     );                                                                     } 

               else { 

                              Application.showMessage( 
                                  ApplicationMessageType.Error, 
                                  "Failed to add to: " + childEvent.getId() 
                              ); 
               }                              
        }  
       else { 
                        count++; 
                        arrayFailedEvent.push(childEvent.getId());                                        arrayFailedEventName.push(calIntegration1.getCalendarEventById(childEvent.getId()).getName());  
                        Application.showMessage( 
                            ApplicationMessageType.Error, 
                            "Failed to remove from: " + childEvent.getId() 
                        ); 
       }                         
    } 
}

5. Output Error Messages and Result Prompts

  • If there are failed events, display the number of failures.
  • For each failed event, show its name and ID.
  • Finally, display a " Finished processing all processes and tasks " message.
var count_string = ConvertUtils.numberToString(count);
// Check if any events failed to replace. If so, output the number of these events.
if(count !== 0){
               Application.showMessage(
               ApplicationMessageType.Warning,
               "You have \"" + count_string + "\" events where the assignee failed to be replaced successfully." 
               );
} 
for (var j = 0; j < count; j++) {
               warningMessage = warningMessage + "The assignee of event  \"" + arrayFailedEventName[j]  + "\" failed to be replaced successfully.\n";
               warningMessage = warningMessage + " the event ID: " + arrayFailedEvent[j] + "\n\n";
}
if (warningMessage) {
               Application.showMessage(
               ApplicationMessageType.Warning,
               warningMessage
               );
}
// Task execution completed.  
Application.showMessage(
              ApplicationMessageType.Info,
             "Finished processing all processes and tasks"
);

V. Summary

This article mainly shares my experience in developing the story application for "Batch Modifying Calendar Process Assignees". If you have encountered similar problems, I hope it can provide you with some inspiration.

entry.title: Announcement: SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud Availability via SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) is a fully managed SaaS solution that unifies and governs all SAP data and seamlessly connects with third-party data, giving line-of-business leaders context to make even more impactful decisions.

Learn more: SAP Business Data Cloud | SAP

SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud are core component services of BDC.  Both services remain strategic to SAP and will continue to be enhanced through their own roadmaps, offered via SAP Business Data Cloud.

SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud are scheduled to be removed from the list of Eligible Cloud Services for new BTPEA, CPEA, and PAYG subscriptions as of January 1, 2026.  

What does this mean for customers? 

These services will be available until the end of a customer’s current BTPEA, CPEA, or PAYG agreement terms.  After December 31, 2025, these services will not be available for renewal. While the services will not be available for renewal terms, the same services will continue to be available in SAP Business Data Cloud.

Existing BTPEA and CPEA customers who purchase cloud credits before January 1, 2026, will be able to continue to use their cloud credits for SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud for the duration of their agreements.

Although customers can continue their current BTPEA, CPEA, and PAYG agreements, there is no need to wait to move to SAP Business Data Cloud.  Customers can now begin their transition plans to SAP BDC.  Please contact your SAP Account team to support your plans.

Note: Existing SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud tenants will be preserved under SAP BDC, no technical migration required. 

 

SAP Analytics Cloud in this blog refers to the following:

  • SAP Analytics Cloud for business intelligence, public system option
  • SAP Analytics Cloud for planning, standard edition, public system option
  • SAP Analytics Cloud for planning, professional edition, public system option
  • SAP Analytics Cloud, test tenant, public system option

entry.title: SAP Analytics Business Intelligence Statement of Direction – July 2025 update
entry.content:
The SAP Analytics Business Intelligence Statement of Direction provides guidance to our SAP BusinessObjects customers on the product directions for SAP analytics solutions. We published a new version this month with some important updates which can be found here.

 

SAP Business Data Cloud

SAP Business Data Cloud delivers deep integration of Data Management, Analytics and Planning augmented by AI in one native cloud solution. This allows to move from insight to action, brings analytics closer to the point of decision and provides trusted insights from customers’ most valuable data.

SAP Analytics Cloud, as a key component of SAP Business Data Cloud, provides trustworthy analytics for any user from any context and remains the recommended option for all new planning and analytics projects. The closed loop from insight to action allows customers to identify challenges, analyze options and execute decisions from one place.

Our knowledge of customer data and integration to business process enable customers to rapidly deploy analytics to address their most important business problems.

 

SAP BusinessObjects BI

With more than 30 years of innovations, SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence platform (SAP BusinessObjects BI) equips thousands of companies which reliably manage enterprise reporting use cases at scale. Our revised maintenance strategy guarantees Mainstream Maintenance until at least end of 2031 which secures your investments on the long run, whether you want to deploy on premise or in a private cloud.

New maintenance strategy

Starting with BI 4.3, Mainstream Maintenance is now followed by Customer Specific Maintenance during which we deliver fixes for high and very high security issues (CVSS >= 7) during the first year. We are extending BI 4.3 Mainstream Maintenance until end of 2026 so that security fixes are guaranteed until end of 2027 as previously committed.

With SAP BusinessObjects BI 2025, we adopt a revised delivery cycle which addresses the need for more stability while keeping regular updates: we are moving away from support packages delivered every year and supported only during 18 months to minor releases delivered every 2 years, benefiting from 3 years of Mainstream Maintenance, followed Customer Specific Maintenance including 1 year of security fixes.

We already plan for a next release, BI 2027, which should be available in Q1 2027, followed by another one 2 years later, and we will revisit our roadmap on a regular basis.

SAP BusinessObjects BI 2025 and beyond

SAP BusinessObjects BI 2025 is available since March 2025. This new version illustrates our strategy going forward: continue the modernization started in version 4.3 and streamline the suite by focusing on the core components while providing alternatives for unsupported ones.

Our strategy is based on 3 pillars: reach more business users, increase power users’ productivity and reduce total cost of ownership. To maximize the value for our customers, we will focus ongoing investments on the most-widely adopted SAP BusinessObjects BI solutions: SAP BusinessObjects Web Intelligence, single source .unx universes, SAP Crystal Reports, and the SAP BusinessObjects BI platform.

 SAP Analysis for Microsoft Office and SAP Lumira Designer will be maintained and supported, but no new feature will be delivered.

We will provide alternatives

With SAP BusinessObjects BI 2025, we do not deliver anymore SAP Lumira Discovery, SAP Crystal Reports for Enterprise, SAP BusinessObjects Universe Design Tool and .unv universes, multi-source universes and associated connectivity, SAP BusinessObjects Analysis edition for OLAP, SAP BusinessObjects Live Office and SAP BusinessObjects Mobile, but we are recommending alternatives for all use cases.

We will stop supporting AIX and Solaris after version 4.3 and will focus on Windows and Linux.

 

Move your analytics to the cloud

For companies willing to move analytics workloads to the cloud, we offer 2 complementary options: SAP BusinessObjects BI operated in a private cloud and SAP Business Data Cloud.

SAP BusinessObjects, private cloud edition is an opportunity to shift from a maintenance contract to a subscription model while leveraging your existing investments in SAP BusinessObjects BI solutions.

SAP Business Data Cloud is recommended for new applications, use cases and users, and along with our partner community, we are committed to support every customer through this journey with tools and programs.

 

Want to learn more?

Enjoy right now the full SAP Analytics Business Intelligence Statement of Direction.

entry.title: Using BW variable as page Filter in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) for Multi-Model Stories
entry.content:
Introduction / Use Case:

In SAC, it is common to use BW variable as a story filter to enable dynamic data filtering.

This approach works well when your story is based on a single BW query or model.

However, Challenges arise when building stories that span multiple pages and use different BW models. In such cases:

  • Each page may rely on a distinct BW query.
  • Some models might not include BW variables and instead use input controls for filtering.

This mixed-model environment prevents the use of a unified story-level filter. To address this, I will demonstrate how to implement a page level filter using a global variable, dropdown, and script logic to dynamically update BW variable at runtime.

Key Notes:

  • The BW query designed with a mandatory variable, which defaults to the current fiscal period (e.g., June 2025). ensuring the query always retrieves data for the latest period.
  • This blog shows how to override and control that variable dynamically using a Page-level filter.

Solution Overview:

We will implement a dropdown filter that drives a global variable, which in turn updates BW query variable at the page level. This approach enables consistent filtering across different models.

Step-by-step Implementation:

  1. Create a Global variable

           Name: VAR_PAYEAR_00

           Type: String

                     

          This variable will serve as the filter carrier and will dynamically update based on the dropdown selection. 

      2. Add a dropdown :

           Name : DRPD_PRYR

           Data Source : Manual Input

           Dropdown Properties:

           Enable write-back at runtime

           Assign to global variable VAR_PAYEAR_00

           Enable input suggestions

            

                            

      3. Create a Dummy Table

           Name: Table_1

           Used to bind the dropdown to a data source for scripting purposes.

       4. Configure Dropdown Onselect Script

           

            var yyyy = DRPD_PRYR.getSelectedKey().slice(2,6);

            var mm = DRPD_PRYR.getSelectedKey().slice(6,8);

           //Fiscal year Format

           VAR_PAYEAR_00 = yyyy+mm;

           Table_1.getDataSource().setVariableValue("VCALMONTH_MSCC001", VAR_PAYEAR_00);

           (BW query variable name : VCALMONTH_MSCC001)

       5. Go to page oninitialization:

           To set default current period and populate the dropdown with the past 24 periods.

            

// Get Current Date to derive current Fiscal Year / Period			
var current_date = new Date(Date.now());			
var date_millisec = current_date.setDate(current_date.getDate());			
var new_date = new Date(date_millisec);			
var date_new_format = new_date.toJSON().slice(0,10);			
var mm = date_new_format.slice(5,7);			
var mon = ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(mm); // Month as Number			
var yyyy = date_new_format.slice(0,4);			
var year =ConvertUtils.stringToInteger(date_new_format.slice(0,4)); // Year as Number			
VAR_PAYEAR_00 = "K4"+yyyy+mm;			
//Current Period			
console.log("Current Period is" + VAR_PAYEAR_00);		



// Populate Previous 24 periods
  // Use a loop to add previous periods to the dropdown and set the default to the most recent period 	
		
var DRPRD_count = 1;

for ( var ipryr = 1; ipryr < 24; ipryr++){
	
if ( mon === 1) //January
		{
       VAR_PAYEAR_00 = "K4"+year.toString()+"0"+mon.toString();
       DRPD_PRYR.addItem(VAR_PAYEAR_00, ( "January " + year.toString() ) );
       console.log("Derived Previous Period " + VAR_PAYEAR_00);
			
	if (( ipryr === 1 ) && (DRPRD_count === 1 ) )
       {
	console.log("Closed Period(Previous Period) " + VAR_PAYEAR_00);	
        DRPD_PRYR.setSelectedKey(VAR_PAYEAR_00);
	DRPRD_count = DRPRD_count + 1;   
       }
		    mon = 12;
		   year = year - 1;
			
		}
if( mon === 2) //February
		{
      VAR_PAYEAR_00 ="K4"+year.toString()+"0"+mon.toString();
      DRPD_PRYR.addItem(VAR_PAYEAR_00, ( "February " + year.toString() ) );
      console.log("Derived Previous Period " + VAR_PAYEAR_00);
	if (( ipryr === 1 ) && (DRPRD_count === 1) )
       {
	console.log("Closed Period(Previous Period) " + VAR_PAYEAR_00);	
	DRPD_PRYR.setSelectedKey(VAR_PAYEAR_00);
        DRPRD_count = DRPRD_count + 1;
       }
			mon = mon - 1;	
		
		}
if( mon === 3) //March 
		{
	VAR_PAYEAR_00 =  "K4"+year.toString()+"0"+mon.toString();
	DRPD_PRYR.addItem(VAR_PAYEAR_00, ( "March " + year.toString() ) );
	console.log("Derived Previous Period " + VAR_PAYEAR_00);
	if (( ipryr === 1 ) && (DRPRD_count === 1 ) )
       {
	console.log("Closed Period(Previous Period) " + VAR_PAYEAR_00);	
	DRPD_PRYR.setSelectedKey(VAR_PAYEAR_00);
	DRPRD_count = DRPRD_count + 1;	 
       }
			mon = mon - 1;
		
		}
if( mon === 4) //April  
		 {
	VAR_PAYEAR_00 = "K4"+year.toString()+"0"+mon.toString();
	DRPD_PRYR.addItem(VAR_PAYEAR_00, ( "April " + year.toString() ) );
	console.log("Derived Previous Period " + VAR_PAYEAR_00); 
	if (( ipryr === 1 ) && (DRPRD_count === 1 ) )

		 }
if( mon === 5) //May  
		{

	DRPD_PRYR.addItem(VAR_PAYEAR_00, ( "May " + year.toString() ) );

        DRPRD_count = DRPRD_count + 1;

			mon = mon - 1;

if( mon === 6) //June

	DRPD_PRYR.addItem(VAR_PAYEAR_00, ( "June " + year.toString() ) );

	DRPRD_count = DRPRD_count + 1;	 
       }
			mon = mon - 1;
		
		}
if( mon === 7) //July   
	    {
	VAR_PAYEAR_00 = "K4"+year.toString()+"0"+mon.toString();
	DRPD_PRYR.addItem(VAR_PAYEAR_00, ( "July " + year.toString() ) );
	console.log("Derived Previous Period " + VAR_PAYEAR_00);
	if (( ipryr === 1 ) && (DRPRD_count === 1 ) )
       {
	console.log("Closed Period(Previous Period) " + VAR_PAYEAR_00);	
	DRPD_PRYR.setSelectedKey(VAR_PAYEAR_00);
	DRPRD_count = DRPRD_count + 1;		 
       }
			mon = mon - 1;
		
		}	
if( mon === 8) //August   
		{
	VAR_PAYEAR_00 = "K4"+year.toString()+"0"+mon.toString();
	DRPD_PRYR.addItem(VAR_PAYEAR_00, ( "August " + year.toString() ) );
	console.log("Derived Previous Period " + VAR_PAYEAR_00);
	if (( ipryr === 1 ) && (DRPRD_count === 1 ) )
       {
	console.log("Closed Period(Previous Period) " + VAR_PAYEAR_00);	
	DRPD_PRYR.setSelectedKey(VAR_PAYEAR_00);
	DRPRD_count = DRPRD_count + 1;
		 
       }
			mon = mon - 1;
		
		}
if( mon === 9) //September  
		{
     VAR_PAYEAR_00 = "K4"+year.toString()+"0"+mon.toString();
     DRPD_PRYR.addItem(VAR_PAYEAR_00, ( "September " + year.toString() ) );
     console.log("Derived Previous Period " + VAR_PAYEAR_00);
	if (( ipryr === 1 ) && (DRPRD_count === 1 ) )
       {
	console.log("Closed Period(Previous Period) " + VAR_PAYEAR_00);	
	DRPD_PRYR.setSelectedKey(VAR_PAYEAR_00);
	DRPRD_count = DRPRD_count + 1;		 
       }
			mon = mon - 1;
		
		}
if ( mon === 10) //October  
		{
       VAR_PAYEAR_00 = "K4"+year.toString()+mon.toString();
       DRPD_PRYR.addItem(VAR_PAYEAR_00, ( "October " + year.toString() ) );
       console.log("Derived Previous Period " + VAR_PAYEAR_00);
	if (( ipryr === 1 ) && (DRPRD_count === 1 ) )
       {
	console.log("Closed Period(Previous Period) " + VAR_PAYEAR_00);	
	DRPD_PRYR.setSelectedKey(VAR_PAYEAR_00);
	DRPRD_count = DRPRD_count + 1;		 
       }
			mon = mon - 1;
		
		}
if( mon === 11) //November
		{
      VAR_PAYEAR_00 = "K4"+year.toString()+mon.toString();
      DRPD_PRYR.addItem(VAR_PAYEAR_00, ( "November " + year.toString() ) );
      console.log("Derived Previous Period " + VAR_PAYEAR_00);
	if (( ipryr === 1 ) && (DRPRD_count === 1 ) )
       {
	console.log("Closed Period(Previous Period) " + VAR_PAYEAR_00);	
	DRPD_PRYR.setSelectedKey(VAR_PAYEAR_00);
	DRPRD_count = DRPRD_count + 1;		 
       }
			mon = mon - 1;
		
		}
if( mon === 12) //December  
		{
      VAR_PAYEAR_00 = "K4"+year.toString()+mon.toString();
      DRPD_PRYR.addItem(VAR_PAYEAR_00, ( "December " + year.toString() ) );
      console.log("Derived Previous Period " + VAR_PAYEAR_00);
	if (( ipryr === 1 ) && (DRPRD_count === 1 ) )
       {
	console.log("Closed Period(Previous Period) " + VAR_PAYEAR_00);	
	DRPD_PRYR.setSelectedKey(VAR_PAYEAR_00);
	DRPRD_count = DRPRD_count + 1;
		 
       }
			mon = mon - 1;
		}
	
	}

                       

Outcome:

  • The dropdown is auto-populated with the previous 24 periods.
  • The most recent period is selected by default.
  • On selection, the corresponding BW variable (VCALMONTH_MSCC001) is dynamically updated.
  • This enables the filter to work at the page level

Note:

To default the filter to the previous period (i.e., current period-1), Update

“if (( ipryr === 1 ) && (DRPRD_count === 1 ) )” to “if (( ipryr === 2 ) && (DRPRD_count === 1 ) )”

This will select the second most recent period (i.e., current period-1) as the default in the dropdown and apply it to BW variable.

Conclusion:

This solution provides a flexible alternative to using story-level filters in complex multi-model SAC stories. By leveraging global variables, dropdown input controls, and scripting, you can achieve dynamic page-level filtering across diverse BW data sources. This improves usability and enhances the dynamic nature of your SAC dashboards.

entry.title: A Beginners guide to SAP BDC
entry.content:
Many developers have contacted me in message box asking how to start with learning SAP BDC.

SAP Has provided many learning paths for same which are available on the Learning hub, but, what about people who don’t have access to learning hub or someone who is still working in legacy technologies.

Sharing these learning links hoping that this will help atleast a few people who trying to learn SAP BDC.

 

Core Components of SAP BDC system

Layer

Description

Source Systems

Includes SAP S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, and external systems. Data is bundled into entities like tables and views for replication.

Foundation Services

Harmonizes and transforms raw data into Data Products. These are stored in a hyperscaler environment (SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake files).

SAP Datasphere

Acts as the semantic layer. Defines data models, manages access control, and supports both prebuilt and custom analytical scenarios.

SAP Databricks

Embedded AI/ML engine for advanced analytics. Enables pro-code engineering and machine learning extensions.

SAP Analytics Cloud

Provides visualization, planning, and ad-hoc analysis capabilities. Powers dashboards and intelligent applications.

BDC Cockpit

Central hub for managing Data Products, Intelligent Applications, and data sharing workflows.

 

You must learn SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics cloud to be ready for SAP BDC.

 

You may use below link to learn more about SAP Datasphere.

Get Started with Your Trial in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials

This mission is the ideal starting point for newcomers to start using SAP Datasphere, get their trial account, and learn the fundamentals for modelling their data in SAP Datasphere.

This training will cover below activities.

  1. Get to Know the SAP Datasphere Interface | SAP Tutorials : talks about how to navigate the user interface of SAP Datasphere and what the home screen controls can do for you
  2. Add Users and Assign Roles in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to add users into your SAP Datasphere tenant, how to assign roles to users, How to edit users in bulk
  3. Create and Monitor a Space in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to create a Space and how to manage and monitor your Space
  4. Create an Entity Relationship Model in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about overview of E/R Models, how to create an E/R Model, how to associate data columns and how to finalise an E/R Model and deploy
  5. Create a Graphical View in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : talks about graphical views, how to create them, how to rename and restore columns in Graphical view and their deployment
  6. Define Measures and Add Business Information to a View | SAP Tutorials talks about what is semantic information, how to define measures, how to add business information, how to change business names of measures and attributes, how to change the semantic type of measures and attributes and how to preview your modelled dataset
  7. Generate Time Table and Dimensions | SAP Tutorials talks about how to create time tables and dimensions and how to associate the time dimensions with your data
  8. Upload Flat Files and Wrangle Your Data | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to upload flat files in the Data Builder of SAP Datasphere, how to make the best of the Data Builder capabilities during a file upload process and how to transform the data for data consistency and integrity
  9. Replicate Data into SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to check the type of data access, how to create a real time data replication and how to schedule the data replication
  10. Integrate and Monitor Data with SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to access the Data Integration Monitor, how to use the Data Integration Monitor dashboard and the types of monitoring you can do with the Data Integration Monitor

 

 

You can use below links to know more about SAP Analytics cloud.

  1. Exploring SAP Analytics Cloud
  2. Create a Live Data Connection in SAP Analytics Cloud | SAP Tutorials
  3. Create Live Data Model and a Story | SAP Tutorials
  4. Develop and Consume Queries on SAP Analytics Cloud | SAP Tutorials

SAP has basic trial versions for both SAP Datasphere and SAC where you may get some hands on knowledge to perform few activities.

Get started with Basic Trial | SAP Tutorials

 

Once you have a good understanding of SAP Datasphere and SAC, you can start going through SAP BDC learning paths.

Introducing SAP Business Data Cloud

 

You may also go through below blogs

SAP BDC for Dummies - SAP Community

SAP BDC Key Features - SAP Community

Deep Dive into SAP BDC Data products - SAP Community

 

Happy Learning!

 

Swati Gawade-Shingade.

Cognizant technology Solutions.

entry.title: How to Collect a HTTP Archive (HAR file) from the SAC Mobile App: A Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
Ensuring the smooth performance of the SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) mobile app is essential for maintaining user satisfaction and productivity. While you might be familiar with troubleshooting network performance issues in desktop environments, the mobile landscape presents its own unique challenges. One effective way to identify and address performance bottlenecks in the SAC mobile app is by collecting and analyzing a HTTP Archive (HAR file).

With this blog, I am expanding upon and further elaborating on some of the points mentioned in my previous blog - Strategy for troubleshooting network performance issues in SAP Analytics Cloud. 

Why Collect a HAR File? 

A HAR file contains detailed information about network requests and responses, including timings, headers, and content. This data is invaluable for diagnosing performance issues and understanding how the app interacts with backend services.

Prerequisites

This guide uses Fiddler Classic for Windows as an example to capture traffic from iOS Device, but another a web debugging proxy tool with similar functionality can also be used to collect the HAR file.  If you're looking for Fiddler for macOS, use Fiddler Everywhere or use virtualization products like VMWare Fusion or Parallels Desktop to run Fiddler Classic in a virtual machine on your Mac.  

Step-by-Step Guide

1. Install and Configure Fiddler.
1.1 Download and Install Fiddler:
  • Fiddler Classic: Download and install Fiddler Classic from the official website Telerik.
  • Fiddler Everywhere: Download and install Fiddler Everywhere from the official website Telerik
1.2. Configure Fiddler to Capture Traffic:
  • Fiddler Classic :
    • Follow steps in Capture Traffic from iOS Device.
    • Follow steps in Configure Fiddler Classic for Android Device.
  • Fiddler Everywhere: 
    • Follow steps in Capturing iOS Traffic - Fiddler Everywhere.
    • Follow steps in Capturing Android Traffic - Fiddler Everywhere.
2. Setting Up Your Mobile Device

2.1 Connect Your Mobile Device and Computer to the Same Network:

  • Ensure that both your mobile device and the computer running Fiddler are connected to the same Wi-Fi network.

2.2 Configure Proxy Settings and Trust Fiddler's Root Certificate on Your Mobile Device:

  • Fiddler Classic:
    • Follow steps in Set the iOS Device Proxy on iOS Device.
    • Follow steps in Configure Android Device on Android Device.
  • Fiddler Everywhere:
    • Follow steps in Configuring the Fiddler proxy on iOS Device.
    • Follow steps in Configuring the Fiddler proxy on Android Device.
3. Capturing and Analyzing Network Traffic (Fiddler Classic)

3.1. Start Capturing Traffic:

  • In Fiddler Classic, go to Fiddler's "File" menu, click the "Capture Traffic" button to start capturing network traffic:

  • Open SAC mobile app and SAC Story:

  • All HTTP/HTTPS traffic should now be captured by Fiddler Classic: 

3.2. Analyze the Captured Traffic:
  • Click on a request to see detailed information, including headers, request and response bodies, and timing information: 

  • Once the required traffic is captured it can ben be exported in various formats including HAR File. To do this  go to Fiddler's "File" menu, select "Export Sessions" > "All Sessions", and save the output as a "HTTPArchive v1.2":

Conclusion

By following these steps, you can collect a HAR file from the SAC mobile app, gaining detailed insights into network performance. This information can be used to identify and troubleshoot performance issues, ultimately helping you optimize the app's performance for mobile users.

Call to Action

If you encounter persistent issues or need additional assistance, don't hesitate to reach out to your Technical Quality Manager (TQM), your SAP Account, your Customer Success Partner (CSP), or our central entry channel, the Virtual Project Room (VPR). They can help you leverage support from SAP's Center of Expertise (CoE) for Analytics, Planning, and Consolidation.

entry.title: The Future of Planning in Excel: The SAP Analytics Cloud Add-in as a Strategic Frontend – Part 1/3
entry.content:
Introduction

For many business users in finance and controlling, Microsoft Excel is more than just software — it’s the daily tool for analysis, reporting, and, above all, corporate planning. Its flexibility and familiar environment are unbeatable. But how do you combine this flexibility with the power, security, and scalability of a central planning platform like the SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)?

The answer is the SAP Analytics Cloud Add-in for Microsoft Office. This modern add-in is positioned as the strategic successor to the proven SAP Analysis for Office, bridging the gap between the familiar world of Excel and the powerful in-memory planning engine of SAC.

A Quick Comparison: Analysis for Office vs. SAC Add-in

For anyone who has worked with SAP data in Excel for years, SAP Analysis for Office (AfO) is an old friend. It’s a robust and feature-rich tool, primarily designed for analyzing data from SAP BW and S/4HANA. It is based on traditional COM add-in technology and is heavily focused on querying BEx Queries or CDS Views.

The new SAC Add-in, on the other hand, was built from the ground up as a native frontend for the SAP Analytics Cloud. Here are the key differences and advantages at a glance:

  • Architecture: The SAC add-in is a modern Microsoft Office 365 add-in (based on WebView2). This allows for centralized, cloud-based deployment and management directly from the Microsoft Admin Center—without cumbersome client installations.
  • Connectivity: While AfO connects directly to backend systems like SAP BW, the primary and sole anchor point for the SAC add-in is your SAC tenant. All data, models, and permissions are sourced centrally from SAC.
  • Focus on Planning: The add-in is optimized for SAC planning models. Features like data entry, running data actions, version management, and using planning features are seamlessly integrated. You work in Excel but leverage the full power of the SAC planning engine in the background.
  • Future Strategy: SAP is clearly positioning the SAC add-in as the strategic tool for Excel integration in the cloud world.

The Architecture: Native Planning and „Seamless Integration“ into Datasphere

The true strength of the new approach lies in its seamless architecture. Instead of keeping planning data in separate silos, SAC allows for direct integration with SAP Datasphere.

This concept ensures that planning data entered in Excel via the SAC add-in can be written directly into the underlying structures of SAP Datasphere. The data flow remains consistent and is always controlled by SAC.

Architecture Diagram: Planning with the SAC Add-in
Architecture

Building an Interactive Planning Sheet

A simple data table is just the beginning, but the true strength of the add-in lies in the combination of SAC data and the flexibility of Excel. Our goal is not just to display data, but to design an interactive planning input screen.

1. Define a Clear Layout:

Using the „Builder“ panel, drag the required dimensions into the rows and columns.

 

2. Use Excel Formulas for Ad-Hoc Analysis:

This is the key advantage: you can use native Excel formulas right next to the data loaded from SAC. For example, add a sum column and calculate it with a simple formula like =SUM(C7:E7). This cell updates dynamically as soon as new plan data is entered or changed.

 

3. Add Data Action Triggers:

Currently the excel add in supports triggering Data Actions directly (Multi Actions are planned for Q4 2025).

 

 

That’s it for the first part of this blog series, stay tuned for more advanced/technical content in the next blog post.

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud: Secure by Design and Intelligent by Default
entry.content:
(Jana Subramanian serves as APJ Principal Cybersecurity Advisor and Compliance and has been recognized as a Fellow of Information Privacy (FIP) by the International Association of Privacy Professionals (IAPP). As part of his responsibilities, Jana helps with strategic customer engagements related to topics such as cybersecurity, data privacy, secure data flow, multi-cloud security integration architecture, contractual assurance, audit, and compliance.)

Introduction

In today’s fast-moving business world, data is everywhere—but often stuck in silos, difficult to manage, and even harder to turn into action. SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) helps solve that. It is a fully managed (SaaS) cloud solution that brings together data from both SAP and non-SAP sources, making it easier to unify, govern, and use data across your business. For organizations already using SAP Business Warehouse (SAP BW), BDC offers a clear path to modernize in the cloud. At the core of BDC are Data Products—reusable, trusted datasets enriched with business context—and Intelligent Applications—AI-driven apps that consume these products to automate decisions and actions. By combining tools like SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud into a unified architecture, BDC removes the need for complex data extractions and ensures your data is always analytics ready.

In this blog, we will explore how BDC works, its key building blocks, and the strong security framework that keeps your enterprise data safe and actionable to enable secure by design and intelligent by default.

Core Components of SAP Business Data Cloud

SAP BDC is built upon a robust stack of integrated components, each playing a vital role in its functionality:

  • SAP Datasphere: The bedrock of SAP BDC, Datasphere provides a unified environment for comprehensive data integration, modeling, transformation, and governance. It supports diverse storage options—including high-performance in-memory, cost-effective disk, and object storage—via SAP HANA Cloud and Data Lake. It includes the Unified Semantic Layer, which standardizes business definitions and supports zero-copy data access across SAP and non-SAP tools. This flexibility makes it ideal for managing varied data needs and enables the creation and governance of reusable, business-ready data products.
  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC): Seamlessly integrated with Datasphere, SAC delivers advanced analytics, planning, and predictive capabilities. It provides real-time dashboards, embedded AI/ML insights, and dynamic visualizations that drive both operational efficiency and intelligent decision-making.
  • SAP Databricks: An SAP-managed Databricks runtime natively embedded within BDC, it brings powerful AI/ML, data science, and big data engineering capabilities directly into the SAP ecosystem. Utilizing zero-copy Delta Sharing, it directly accesses governed data products from SAP Datasphere, enabling advanced analytics on both SAP and non-SAP data without the need for replication.
  • The BDC Cockpit: Serving as the central administrative console for SAP Business Data Cloud, the BDC Cockpit allows users to manage roles, configurations, and deployments. For data analysts and data scientists, it also acts as the primary entry point to discover, activate, and monitor data products and intelligent applications.

 Figure 1: SAP Business Data Cloud - Core Components

 

Category

Component/Description

Key Functionality/Characteristics

SOURCE SYSTEMS

SAP S/4HANA (Cloud)

Origin of transactional and operational data

 

SAP SuccessFactors

Origin of HR data

 

SAP Cloud ERP

Origin of enterprise resource planning data

 

SAP BW/4HANA

Origin of historical and analytical data

 

Third-party systems

Origin of external data from non-SAP sources

SAP DATASPHERE

Connectors to source systems (e.g., SDA, DP Agent, JDBC, SDI)

Facilitates data ingestion from diverse sources

(DATA FABRIC LAYER)

Semantic modeling, data lineage, transformation

Defines data meaning, tracks data flow, prepares data for consumption

 

SAP Foundation Services: harmonization + metadata

Ensures data consistency and provides descriptive information about data

 

SAP Databricks runtime for zero-copy access & ML ops

Enables advanced data processing, machine learning operations directly on data without copying

 

Storage in SAP HANA Cloud or Data Lake

Stores integrated and processed data

DATA PRODUCTS LAYER

Curated & governed datasets

Provides ready-to-use, validated, and controlled data assets

 

Based on harmonized views and tables from Datasphere

Data products derived from the structured and harmonized data in Datasphere

 

Include metadata, access policies, lineage

Ensures data discoverability, security, and traceability

INTELLIGENT APPLICATIONS

SAP/Partner-built AI-driven business apps

Applications leveraging AI for specific business functions, built by SAP or partners

 

Use Data Products as input (not raw data)

Consume refined and governed data, not direct source data

 

Automate insights, simulate, forecast

Core capabilities of intelligent applications for business decision support

 

Embedded ML (Joule copilot, time-series models, simulations)

Machine learning capabilities integrated directly within applications, enhancing functionality

BROADER ECOSYSTEM

SAP Analytics (Cloud)

Tools for data visualization, reporting, and business intelligence

 

Joule

AI assistant/copilot for intelligent interactions (likely related to embedded ML)

 

SAP Databricks (used within Datasphere)

Platform for ML workflows & services, analytical queries, direct access to data products

 

GenAI Hub

Centralized hub for Generative AI capabilities and models

With a clear understanding of the components, let’s explore how key architectural principles—like data gravity and zero-copy sharing—bring these components to life. The principle of data gravity dictates processing data where it resides, minimizing unnecessary movement and duplication. This approach dramatically enhances performance, ensures data consistency, and simplifies governance. Building on this, zero-copy sharing allows datasets to be securely shared across different internal services and external platforms, such as SAP Databricks, without physical replication. This innovative capability ensures data freshness, eliminates redundancy, and drastically reduces the operational overhead associated with traditional data duplication.

Principle

Meaning

How SAP BDC Implements It

Data Gravity

Data attracts compute and services to where it resides, minimizing unnecessary movement.

Replicates source data into Datasphere once; downstream consumers access it in place.

Zero-Copy Data Sharing

Share data across services and tools without physically copying it.

Uses Delta Sharing to provide real-time access to data without duplication.

Governance by Design

Embed data quality, access control, and monitoring into the data lifecycle.

Implements RBAC, metadata, certification, and lineage across data products.

Semantic Consistency

Ensure consistent business definitions and semantics across all systems.

Applies Unified Semantic Layer for standard definitions across SAP and non-SAP data.

Open Data Consumption

Expose data through standardized APIs and protocols to support diverse tools.

Supports APIs, JDBC/ODBC, Delta Sharing, and open metadata standards (ORD, CSN).

AI-First Enablement

Design the architecture to natively support AI and machine learning workloads.

Provides curated data products for AI; integrates with SAP Joule and Databricks ML.

Federated but Governed Access

Enable distributed access while maintaining centralized visibility and control.

Formation-based access, central cockpit governance, and role-specific permissions.

Data-as-a-Product

Treat data as reusable, governed assets with clear ownership and lifecycle.

Data Products are cataloged, versioned, governed, and optionally monetized.

Multi-Layer Security in SAP BDC:

Customer Data Isolation:

The diagram above outlines the multi-layered isolation and security model underpinning SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). Each layer—from tenant and application isolation to data access and encryption—is designed to ensure secure separation of customer environments and data. BDC leverages SAP BTP subaccounts, SAP Analytics Cloud spaces, and HANA Cloud schema-level isolation to enforce strong boundaries across structured and unstructured data. Federated identity via SAP IAS and XSUAA, combined with fine-grained RBAC and AppRouter security, ensures only authorized users and apps can access data. Critically, all operational access is just-in-time, logged, and monitored, providing a strong audit trail and compliance posture. This layered defense approach enables secure, scalable, and compliant operations across diverse enterprise landscapes.

 Figure 2: Secure Multi-Layer Isolation

Security in SAP Business Data Cloud is enforced across every architectural layer, from ingestion to consumption. The table below highlights specific security considerations for each core component—covering access controls, identity management, encryption, data governance, and metadata protection. It reflects how BDC applies fine-grained controls using SAP IAS, RBAC, and semantic governance, while supporting zero-copy access and tenant isolation to ensure secure, scalable operations.

Component

Security Considerations

SAP and Non-SAP Source Systems

Source system authentication and authorization managed externally. Integration to BDC via secure connectors like ODP, JDBC, SDI DP Agent, with TLS encryption.

SAP BTP Customer Sub-Account

Tenant-level isolation. Access managed through SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS), role-based access control (RBAC), and audit logging.

SAP Datasphere Instance

Provider-managed, provisioned within customer sub-account. Encrypted data at rest and in transit. Includes data lineage, access control, metadata protection.

SAP Data Products

Granular access control (RBAC), visibility settings (public, private, internal). Metadata includes data lineage, classification, ownership for governance.

SAP Datasphere Semantic Layer

Access control per semantic model. Inherits governance from data products. Metadata visibility is controlled.

SAP Databricks

Zero-copy access with authentication via shared identity provider. Data access governed via semantic layer permissions. Execution isolated in managed environments.

Intelligent Applications

Formation-based access controls. Deployed in provider-managed secure spaces (read-only). Can be copied into customer-managed spaces with RBAC.

SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

User authentication via IAS or SAP Universal ID. Live data connections use secure tunnels. Dashboard access controlled via SAC roles and teams.

Business Users/App UI

User-level permissions defined via roles. Interaction restricted by app layer controls, enforced least privilege access.

Data Scientist

Access to data products governed through RBAC. Execution environments are containerized and isolated. Notebook access secured via SAP-managed identity.

Data Products and Intelligent Applications

Data Product

  1. Standardized, curated, and governed datasets enriched with business context, semantics, and metadata.
  2. Designed for high-volume reuse across analytics, AI, and ML scenarios—reducing the need for custom pipelines or redundant extraction.
  3. Can be developed by SAP, customers, or partners.
  4. Stored flexibly across SAP Datasphere and SAP HANA Cloud Data Lake, supporting zero-copy access for downstream tools like SAP Databricks.
  5. Easily discoverable and installable through the BDC Cockpit and Data Marketplace, which provide rich metadata and role-based access control.
  6. Typically installed into customer-managed SAP Datasphere spaces, allowing customization while preserving governance.

Intelligent Application

  1. Prebuilt, AI-infused apps developed by SAP and partners to automate and optimize business workflows.
  2. Use Data Products as inputs for planning, simulation, forecasting, and decision support.
  3. Deploy with supporting assets like SAP Analytics Cloud dashboards, semantic models, and predefined logic.
  4. Designed for business users to interact with real-time insights securely and intuitively—no data wrangling required.

 Figure 3: Data Products and Intelligent Application

 

Security Domain

Data Products Layer

Intelligent Applications

Access Control

RBAC, Authentication via IAS, Delta Sharing policies

Formation-based access, user assignment controls app/data scope

Metadata & Lineage

ORD & CSN Standards, Data Product Certification

Transparent logic, knowledge graphs, semantic awareness, based on trusted data

Encryption

At Rest: SAP KMS; In Transit: TLS 1.2+

Same encryption as Data Products

Identity & Access

2FA via IAS/Universal ID

Inherits identity context, JSON Token, Scope, Role Collection; 2FA enforced via login

Responsibility Model

SAP: Infra & Platform Security

Customer: Roles, Identity Policies, Visibility

Conclusion

SAP Business Data Cloud is a secure and AI-ready platform that helps businesses manage and use complex data from across their systems. Built on technologies like SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Databricks, it ensures data is high-quality, governed, and well-protected. At its core are Data Products—reusable, trusted datasets that follow a “data-as-a-product” model. These products are secured, certified by SAP, and governed through centralized policies.

Layered on top are Intelligent Applications, which use these data products to automate decisions across business processes. With support for both SAP and non-SAP data, and powered by advanced AI tools, these apps deliver fast, accurate insights to drive better outcomes.

entry.title: What's New in SAP BTP – Q2 2025
entry.content:
Q2 was another big quarter for SAP Business Technology Platform. From application development to integration and analytics, we are excited to share how SAP BTP continues to simplify, streamline, and speed things up! Let's dive into some of the top innovations!

App Dev & Automation Highlights 

Simplified SAPUI5 extensions with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard 

If your business relies on cloud ERP as its IT backbone, you know it may need extensions to meet unique requirements. When built-in extensibility isn’t enough, SAP Build on SAP BTP offers powerful options for custom coding and SAP Fiori UI extensions.  

Now, with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard, you can create UI extensions directly from your cloud ERP application. By launching the Extensibility Wizard directly from your SAP Fiori application, you are given different options for the type of extension you want to create.

The 'User Interface Extension' lets you either adapt the existing Fiori app or create a new custom application. By setting up your destinations and details in the Wizard, you can either remove sections, add new fields, and create a completely new variant of the application with SAP Build Code and Business Application Studio. Developers and key users can already use it to create custom processes and now, custom user interfaces. 

Watch the video demo (starting at 0:08)  for more insights!   

Learn more:  Simplify SAPUI5 Code Extensions with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard

Application to Enable Business Users to Manage Decisions

To empower business users to view or maintain decisions within SAP Build Process Automation, we launched a dedicated, purpose-built application that can be accessed directly from SAP Build Work Zone – without the need of IT. 

Business users can access a dedicated application in SAP Build Work Zone to manage decisions within a single project. Users can open the decision table, modify values directly, or import data from Excel and then save their changes, seeing only what matters and making the experience clean and focused. The release of a changed version is only one click away. Any errors are shown in the design console, letting users view the different versions of the project. 

See for yourself in the demo (starting at 2:05)  for more insights!

Learn more 

  • Configure the Stuido Home Application 
  • Using the Studio Home Application

Partner Solutions as an Installable Product on SAP BTP ABAP Environment 

Good news for SAP partners developing apps with SAP BTP ABAP Environment: you can now offer your solution not only as a multitenant Software as a Service solution, but also as an installable product! 

Customers can now install the solution directly in their system as a product. As a part of SAP BTP ABAP Environment, the Landscape Portal supports both delivery options: multitenant SaaS and installable product. 

You can do this in three easy steps:

  1. Build your product with the Register Product app. 
  2. Choose your delivery model: 
    • For multitenant SaaS, configure it in the Maintain Solution app  
    • For installable product, use the Publish Product app. 
  3. Publish your solution to the SAP Store with a PartnerEdge Build contract and an SAP Store enhancement. 

Now customers using SAP BTP ABAP Environment can find your product in the SAP Store and install it into their own system using the Deploy Product option. 

For detailed guidance, watch the demo (starting at 3:42). 

Learn more: Building partner products on SAP BTP ABAP Environment

Integration Highlight

Describe Externalized Parameters of an Integration Flow 

In SAP Integration Suite externalization enables integration developers to define parameters as variables for certain configurations of adapters or flow steps of an integration flow. The values of these parameters can be changed without editing the integration flow, for example, when moving integrations from development or test environment to production. To simplify the understanding of this difficult and technical process, content developers can now provide descriptions directly in the integration flow editor. These can be the potential values, examples or additional details explaining the impact of specific values which will then be visible for guiding through each of the fields in the Configure view. This brings huge potential to improve the maintainability and reusability of your integration scenarios.  

Take a look at the demo (starting at 5:21) and see for yourself! 

Learn more: Externalized Parameters View

Data & Analytics Highlight

Analytical insights in Joule 

Joule, SAP's copilot, now enables you to get quick analytical answers without having to build reports. This provides you with valuable insights, saving time and giving you the information you need. 

Joule scans available data sources and suggests a few options, making comparisons to previous months easier. Joule updates the view right away, making it easy to see how things are trending. For example, you can ask for the top ten sales agents, check the monthly commission trend from January to March, giving you contextual and relevant answers 

See this in action in the demo (starting 7:15).

Learn more: Introducing Analytical Insights in Joule: Empowering Smarter Decisions, Instantly

Cross Platform Highlight

Provision App-Specific Groups in Identity Directory 

SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant enables immediate provisioning of authorizations to target systems in SAP Analytics Cloud target system. You can  centrally manage user-group assignments linked to application-specific policies, triggering provisioning jobs that synchronize access rights efficiently and securely. This ensures users gain prompt access to their designated roles in the target system.

Watch the demo (starting at 8:37) for a closer look. 

Learn more: SAP Cloud Identity Services

Share your thoughts 

These videos are for YOU. We would love to hear your impressions. How do you like the video? How can we improve the upcoming videos? Please share your feedback by liking this post or leaving a comment below.

Thank you for your support and happy viewing, sharing, and enjoying!

You Might Also Be Interested In

  • SAP BTP Garage: monthly LIVE webinar with hands-on use case walkthroughs and demos.
  • SAP BTP Talk Podcast: monthly podcast covering all things SAP BTP.

entry.title: SAP BDC Ecosystem
entry.content:
By now you may have got a good understanding of SAP BDC components from my earlier blogs.

Now let's try to see how it all fits together.

 

 

At the first level we start with the data repository source. It may be an SAP system (like SAP S/4, Success Factor, SAP BW etc. )  or any non-SAP system.

Customers struggle a lot in heterogeneous system where data is stored in multiple different data storage systems. This data is vital for reporting.

 

For the data-driven modern organisations, having convenient access to all the necessary data in a specific and centralised location is important. Easy, convenient access ensures that data resources are always available at a moment’s notice, easing the process for you and allowing you to conduct all operations. 

 

With SAP BDC, various in-built SAP provided connectors available which we can use to connect to SAP as well as non-SAP systems and integrate them as a source of information i.e. transactional & master data.

SAP BDC system resides in SAP BTP platform similar to SAP Datasphere tenant sub-accounts currently. 

You will have a separate SAP Datasphere instance inside your SAP BDC environment.

SAP Datasphere is the evolution of the SAP data warehouse(earlier SAP BW) solution in the cloud, combining capabilities from SAP Data Warehouse Cloud with its agile enterprise data warehouse, self-service data modelling and SAP Data Intelligence Cloud with its data orchestration, lineage, quality, among other capabilities.

In data integration projects, a lot of time is spent trying to recreate context that has been lost during data replication, especially when getting data from the database layer belonging to heterogeneous storage systems.

With SAP BDC, customers will be able to bring all the structured and non-structured data under single umbrella in business data fabric.

This simplifies complex data landscapes and delivers meaningful data to every data consumer, be it Data architect, business user or a decision maker – it takes the benefits and value further by keeping the business logic and application context from data intact.

For each of the source systems, SAP has provided ready-to-use data products which can be found in SAP BDC Cockpit.

To use out-of-the-box Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud with third-party data, first browse the available Data Products in the SAP Business Data Cloud Cockpit. Then select and install the one that best meets your requirements before proceeding with integration.

 

 

 

 SAP BDC system eliminates the need to recreate all the business context lost from extracting data - giving business stakeholders and data consumers the ability to accelerate their decision-making with trust and confidence, knowing they always have the complete picture of their data regardless of where it is stored or how it was designed.

 

SAP Data products are combination of curated views & tables, metadata, access control, inbound and outbound interfaces, load capabilities, data lineage etc. which are used by semantic layer in SAP Datasphere by consumption ready data models which can be then used for internal data manipulation and transformation.

 

This data can then be used for

  1. Reporting by SAP Analytics cloud through live data, dashboards and stories
  2. AI/ML capabilities by Databricks for powerful compute and advance analytics
  3. Visualization by intelligent apps for business users to interact with real-time insights securely and intuitively

 

SAP BDC replicates source data into Datasphere object store once; downstream consumers access it from there.

With use of delta Sharing , Databricks gets real-time access to data without duplication saving storage space and associated costs.

 

 

 

All in all, SAP BDC is built upon a robust stack of integrated components, each playing a vital role in its functionality.

  • SAP BDC combines SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and their capabilities into one fully managed SaaS solution for all data and analytics needs.
  • It seamlessly integrates mission-critical SAP data with third-party sources—without losing business context or requiring constant extraction.
  • SAP transforms and harmonizes business data within a hyperscaler environment, ensuring high-quality, ready-to-use data across the board.
  • Prebuilt SAP Business Data Cloud Intelligent Applications deliver instant, AI-powered business insights with minimal setup, accelerating decision-making and innovation.

 

Ultimately, SAP BDC helps organizations:

  • Streamline operations with advanced data pipelines
  • Accelerate innovation through AI and predictive analytics
  • Improve agility by enabling teams to respond to change quickly
  • Drive business growth by turning data into a competitive advantage

 

Happy Learning!

 

Swati Gawade-Shingade.

Cognizant technology Solutions.

You may also go through below blogs

SAP BDC for Dummies - SAP Community

SAP BDC Key Features - SAP Community

Deep Dive into SAP BDC Data products - SAP Community

entry.title: Data Lineage – Do it Yourself with SAP HANA and SAC
entry.content:
Management Summary 

  1. Data lineage is crucial for understanding the origin and usage of data – a central requirement for data governance, data quality, and efficient data management. 
  2. With SAP HANA and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), a cost-effective and quickly implementable solution for data lineage can be realized, as both products are already included in the licensing of many companies. 
  3. The Object Dependencies in SAP HANA provide comprehensive information about dependencies between tables, views, and other objects, which can be directly read in SAC via a live connection. 
  4. Thanks to the R-integration in SAC (e.g., with the R package "collapsibleTree"), an interactive tree representation is created, offering business users an intuitive and transparent overview of data flows and relationships. 
  5. This approach enables an automated, real-time view of data origin, improves the maintainability of reports and data models, and lays the foundation for reliable and data governance-compliant analytics applications.

Introduction

In modern data warehouse architectures, data lineage plays an increasingly important role. Companies want to trace where data comes from, how it is transformed, and in which reports it is ultimately used. Transparent data origin significantly contributes to data quality and governance. It also creates data understanding and facilitates the implementation of reporting requirements, especially in self-service environments.

Companies with an SAP tech stack are often familiar with the principle of data lineage from SAP BW, where data flows can be visualized via the data flow object. However, in modern system landscapes where SAP BW is combined with SAP HANA – for example, through hybrid architectures with native HANA views and BW objects – this visualization reaches its limits. In native HANA development, such visualization options are even completely missing.

Although established tools like Collibra or D-QUANTUM offer comprehensive lineage functions, they require additional licenses, implementation effort and a structuring of organizational process to get the full potential out of the tools. For many use cases – such as error analysis or the development of new requirements – a lighter solution is sufficient.

Therefore, we looked for a lean and quickly implementable alternative that supports development in complex system landscapes. Our goal: to automatically identify and visualize the dependencies of SAP HANA objects – without additional third-party tools.

In this blog post, we show how to implement a cost-effective and quick visualization of data lineage using SAP HANA Object Dependencies and a live connection to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC). A special highlight: Through the integration of R in SAC (including the R package "collapsibleTree"), data origin is visualized in an interactive tree structure in an SAC story.

 

Motivation: Why Data Lineage?

The requirements for transparency, traceability, and efficiency in data architectures are increasing – especially in regulated and data-driven companies. Data lineage makes a decisive contribution here:

  • Transparency: Knowing the origin and usage of data creates trust and better decision-making foundations.
  • Data understanding: A clear overview of data flows facilitates both operation and the implementation of reporting and analysis requirements.
  • Maintainability: Changes in the data model can be better assessed if the affected downstream objects are known.
  • Compliance: Regulations like GDPR require traceable documentation of data processing.

Many companies already have some form of data lineage – but usually maintained manually by data engineers in PowerPoint, Excel, or Word. The result: high maintenance effort, outdated documentation, and lack of up-to-date information in ongoing operations.

Our solution is based on existing SAP HANA and SAC licenses and combines automated determination of data flows with an interactive representation through R integration. This creates a maintainable, always up-to-date, and interactive overview of data flows – without additional tools or costs.

 

Technical Background: SAP HANA Object Dependencies

SAP HANA provides Object Dependencies in the form of metadata tables and views, where relationships between different objects are stored. Here you can find information about which objects depend on and are linked to each other. A brief overview:

  • Data source: The Objects Dependencies View can be found in the HANA schema SYS under the name OBJECT_DEPENDENCIES.
  • Object types: Tables, views, stored procedures, etc.
  • Dependencies: Relationships between objects, e.g., which tables or views are used for an SAC report.
  • Usage: Supports impact and lineage analyses directly at the database level.

Through a live connection in SAP Analytics Cloud, this information can be queried and visualized in real-time.

Figure 1: Extract from the Object Dependencies | SELECT TOP 1000 * FROM SYS.OBJECT_DEPENDENCIES.

Implementation in SAP Analytics Cloud

To implement the data lineage solution in SAC, two prerequisites must be met:

  • Live connection to SAP HANA: With the HANA live connection the necessary metadata is read from HANA in real time to ensure that it is up to date. This live connection must be created.
  • R server configuration: An R package is used for visualization. The use of R must be activated in SAC.

The necessary steps in order to create the lineage visualization can be summarized as follows:

  • Data preparation in SAP HANA
    • Preparation of metadata: For optimal visualization, the metadata is prepared, e.g., filtering object types, enriching descriptions.
    • Provision as a calculation view: The data is prepared as a calculation view as a basis for the SAC story.
  • Establishing a live connection to HANA
